Quiz.introText: We will ask {count} simple questions to understand exactly where your child is in their development.
Quiz.planSubtitle: Based on your observations, here is what your child needs right now.
Quiz.noSkills: No specific emerging skills observed yet! Keep watching and come back in a week.

gm-pull-stand.title: Pulling to Stand
gm-pull-stand.prompt: Does your child pull themselves up to stand on furniture?
gm-pull-stand.description: Child pulls themselves up on furniture but cannot let go yet.
gm-pull-stand.why: They need stable surfaces to pull up on. Ensure furniture is heavy and won't tip.
gm-pull-stand.details: Create a safe 'pull-up station' by placing a heavy ottoman or low shelf against a wall. Ensure it is sturdy enough to support their weight without tipping. Place a favorite toy on top to motivate them.

gm-cruising.title: Cruising
gm-cruising.prompt: Does your child walk sideways while holding onto the sofa or table?
gm-cruising.why: Place two chairs slightly apart to encourage them to 'bridge the gap'.
gm-cruising.details: Arrage furniture (like a sofa and a chair) with a small gap in between. Place a toy on the second piece of furniture. Watch as your child learns to let go of one to reach the other.

gm-walking.title: Independent Walking
gm-walking.prompt: Has your child taken their first steps without holding onto anything?
gm-walking.description: Taking first independent steps without support.
gm-walking.why: Carrying weight helps them feel their center of gravity and improves balance.
gm-walking.details: Fill a small plastic bottle with water (seal it tight!). The added weight provides proprioceptive feedback, helping them steady their wobble as they walk.

gm-heavy-work.title: Maximum Effort
gm-heavy-work.prompt: Does your child enjoy carrying heavy things or pushing heavy boxes?
gm-heavy-work.description: Carrying heavy objects or pushing heavy things.
gm-heavy-work.why: At this stage, they crave 'Maximum Effort'. Let them carry laundry baskets or water jugs.
gm-heavy-work.details: Give your child a job! Ask them to carry a heavy (but safe) bag of groceries or a jug of water to the kitchen. They will feel immense pride and satisfaction.

fm-pincer.title: Pincer Grasp
fm-pincer.prompt: Can your child pick up a tiny crumb using just their thumb and pointer finger?
fm-pincer.description: Using thumb and index finger to pick up small items.
fm-pincer.why: The coin requires them to align their wrist and use a refined grasp.
fm-pincer.details: Cut a thin slit in the lid of a shoe box. Provide large coins or poker chips. The act of orienting the coin to fit the slot is a major neurological workout.

fm-posting.title: Posting (Insertion)
fm-posting.prompt: Does your child enjoy dropping objects into holes or slots?
fm-posting.description: Putting an object into a hole.
fm-posting.why: They are fascinated by objects disappearing. This builds object permanence.
fm-posting.details: Stick a dry spaghetti noodle into playdough so it stands up. Challenge your child to thread penne pasta onto the 'tower'. This builds incredible hand-eye coordination.

fm-wrist.title: Wrist Rotation
fm-wrist.prompt: Does your child try to turn door knobs or unscrew jar lids?
fm-wrist.why: The wrist rotation is a precursor to writing. The Horizontal Dowel isolates this movement.
fm-wrist.details: Collect clean jars of different sizes. Loosen the lids slightly. Let your child finish unscrewing them to find a small surprise inside.

fm-stacking.title: Precision Stacking
fm-stacking.prompt: Can your child stack 3 blocks on top of each other without them falling?
fm-stacking.why: Stacking requires controlled release. The Vertical Stacker guides this movement.
fm-stacking.details: Start with just 3 blocks. Model how to place one on top of the other slowly. If they knock it down, laugh! Destruction is part of the learning process too.

pl-drinking.title: Drinking from Glass
pl-drinking.prompt: Can your child drink from a small open glass (not a sippy cup)?
pl-drinking.why: Drinking from an open glass teaches cause-and-effect (spilling) and lip control.
pl-drinking.details: Use a very small, heavy shot glass (thick glass is best). Fill it only with a sip of water. Teach them to hold it with two hands.

pl-cleaning.title: Interest in Cleaning
pl-cleaning.prompt: Does your child try to sweep or wipe up spills when they see you doing it?
pl-cleaning.why: They love to imitate you. Spraying strengthens hand muscles.
pl-cleaning.details: Give them a small spray bottle with water and a squeegee. Show them how to spray the window and wipe. It's purposeful work that builds grip strength.
